Mamedov 1"* Catalysis Division, Institute of lnorganic and Physical Chemistry, 29 Azizbekov Avenue, 370143 Baku, Azerbaijan Received 25 February 1994; accepted 4 May 1994 Abstract This review concerns selective oxidation catalysts which often exhibit an increase in activity or/ and selectivity as the reaction proceeds to reach its steady state. The objective is to discuss the possible reasons of this phenomenon. The evidence is presented that the activation of most of the reviewed catalysts was caused by the reaction-induced restructuring observed to occur at the surface as well as in the bulk of catalyst. Different mechanisms, such as removal of weakly bound oxygen, creation of active sites, deposition of carbonaceous material, formation of new phases or overlayers, remote controlled cooperation between separate phases and others, are discussed. These changes in catalyst composition are to be taken into account both for modelling the reaction mechanism and kinetics. Introduction Already in 1921 Langmuir [ 1,2], in his classical papers on catalytic oxidation of carbon monoxide by a platinum wire, wrote that"...the filament was undergoing a progressive change in the direction of becoming a better catalyst... There is a good evidence that the effect is caused by changes in the structure of the surface itself, brought about by the reaction." He expressed intuitively a fact that nowadays has been extensively confirmed by a use of high-resolution techniques for surface studies. In the last two decades, an impressive progress has been made in studying clean metal surfaces which are shown [3-5] to undergo the chemisorption induced rearrangement on the atomic scale as well as restructuring on the mesoscopic level, leading for example to the formation of other crystal planes (facetting). According to Ertl [4], such processes either are driven by thermodynamics, namely the ten- dency to minimize the free energy, or are consequences of the nonlinear dynamics governing the behaviour of systems far from equilibrium. The latter aspects may even lead to non-uniform lateral distributions of the adsorbates (spatio-temporal self-organization), which are possibly associated with oscillatory or chaotic kinet- ics. Surface reconstructions during catalytic reactions and their catalytic consequences have recently been reviewed by Somorjai [ 5 ]. He emphasized three different changes of surface structure occurring on the time scale of chemisorption (less than 10 -6 S) and catalytic reactions (10-2-102 s) and also on longer (102- 104 s) time scales. The latter changes are usually controlled by surface atom transport and can be correlated with catalyst activation and deactivation that are detectable on a similar time scale. Oxidation and reduction of catalysts can also lead to restructuring of this type. The above-mentioned restructuring was observed during the oxidation of carbon monoxide, hydrogen and other small molecules on clean surfaces of transition metals or pure oxides frequently used in the form of monocrystals. One can expect them to take place on the surface of mixed oxides during the selective oxidation of hydrocarbons. Under these conditions, however, the discrimination of the type of surface reconstruction and its responsibility for the corresponding change in cata- lytic performance becomes much more complicated because of different factors. The most important of them seem to be the existence of original defects in the structure of multicomponent catalysts, the presence of several elements at the surface, each of which can serve as an adsorption site, and a variety of intermediates and reaction products able to be adsorbed. Consequently, it is necessary to study separately the reaction kinetics at unchanged steady state of the catalyst (the second multiplier in expression 1 ) and the change of catalyst properties under the influence of reaction mixtures having different composition (the first multiplier in expression 1 ). The former is important for understanding the mechanism of cata- lytic reaction whereas the latter may supply some information on the mechanism of catalyst action and regulation of its activity. It is worthy of note that the changes of the catalyst surface structure occurring in response to its chemical environment cannot be steps of the catalytic reaction. These are side-processes which proceed as a function of time rather slowly in comparison with the catalytic reaction. The restructuring frequently takes place not only at the surface but involves deeper layers even leading to phase transformations. During this process the catalytically active sites and phases can be created or destroyed. This is one of the mechanisms of catalyst activation or deactivation. Sintering and re-dispersion are among the phenomena that are associated with atom transport and surface restructuring. These and other origins of the deactivation phenomena are well studied and repeatedly reviewed [7-9]. Much less attention has been paid for catalyst changes which cause an increase in catalytic activity, in particular taking place during the selective oxidation of hydrocarbons. Boreskov [6,10] discussed in part the results of early publications on the influence of the reaction medium on activity and selectivity of some oxidation catalysts, with the emphasis mainly placed on the surface reduction and phase transformations occurring under the reaction conditions. Other mechanisms of catalyst activation as well as the results of more recent publications have not yet been reviewed. The objective of this paper is to analyze only those cases where the published works report an activation of selective oxidation catalysts under the influence of the reactive atmosphere, and to classify them according to the mechanisms of this process. Surface restructuring 3.1. Surface reduction As a rule, the surface of the steady-state catalyst differs from that of the freshly prepared one. The steady state of the catalyst in the atmosphere of a non-equilibrium reaction mixture normally corresponds to the state that is between the equilibrium states obtained during the catalyst interactions with individual reagents. Since these interactions change the catalyst composition in opposite directions, its steady state depends on the ratio of their rates. Consequently, every composition of the reaction mixture at constant temperature should comply with the corresponding steady-state composition of the catalyst. For oxidation reactions proceeding via a redox mechanism of the Mars-Van Krevelen type, it was postulated [ 11 ] that the oxygen coverage of a steady-state surface would depend on the oxygen-to-oxidizable substrate ratio in the feed stream as well as on the reaction temperature. This is evidenced by many experimental data [ 12-16]. So, the reaction induced formation of stable surface compounds more active than the catalyst by itself appears to be an effective tool for improving catalytic behaviour of acidic oxides in selective oxidation. As shown above, interactions of the com- ponents of the reaction mixture with acid sites of medium-high strength may bring about the deposition of catalytically active coke. It contains active oxygen species, such as quinone/hydroquinone, aroxyl/phenol or carbonyl/carboxyl groups, which act as a redox system [ 38 ]. In this way, the catalyst acquires redox properties which were originally absent or insufficient. This beneficial influence of the reacting mixture on catalytic performance seems also probable for highly acidic zeolites which are now being extensively tested as catalysts for various reactions in selective oxidation. 3.4. Subsurface restructuring This kind of catalyst activation seems to take place during silver catalyzed ethylene epoxidation. Clean silver surfaces yield an initial selectivity of ca. 40% which increases as the reaction proceeds, to reach a higher steady-state value. Such an activation of silver for ethylene epoxidation can be related to the reactive nature of an oxygen adspecies which is influenced by the electronic characteristics and structure of the silver surface. Experimental evidence and theoretical calculations indicate [44] that at least two forms of atomic oxygen exist on silver, namely surface-adsorbed and subsur- face-absorbed oxygen. Subsurface oxygen does not involve mere dissolution of oxygen in bulk, since this state could be completely saturated upon moderate exposure. It is more stable than bulk silver oxide; the range of temperatures and pressures studied in ref. [ 45 ] extended beyond the stability limits of the latter. As for its role in ethylene epoxidation, it has been shown [46] that in the absence of subsurface oxygen, oxygen adsorbed on the silver surface gives only carbon dioxide and water upon reaction with ethylene. In the presence of subsurface oxygen, the nature of the adsorbed oxygen changes and epoxide formation can occur as well. This indicates that subsurface oxygen plays a key role in forming the selective surface for epoxidation. Van Santen and De Groot [ 47] have proposed that acti- vation of a silver surface initially involves the filling of subsurface sites and that E.A. Moreover, they believe that subsurface oxygen atoms become incorporated in the epoxide upon exchange with adsorbed oxygen surface atoms. Most of the mentioned studies were primarily focused on the reactivity of equil- ibrated silver catalysts having known compositions. Recently, Svoboda et al. [48] have investigated the activation of silver powder for ethylene epoxidation at vacuum and atmospheric pressure using transient response techniques based on a TAP (temporal analysis of products) reactor system. The results indicate that the acti- vation process, being qualitatively the same in both pressure regimes, involves a concurrent filling of surface and subsurface sites, but the latter sites are filled at a much slower rate. According to this model, subsurface oxygen does not participate directly in the oxidation reaction but can modify the electronic properties of the surface. Specifically, it can withdraw electron density from the surface, thus increas- ing the electrophilic character of the silver surface atoms and oxygen adspecies, and may also reduce the bond energy between silver and adsorbed oxygen. In both cases, the reaction selectivity is expected to increase. Indeed, the rise in epoxide selectivity has been found to run in parallel with the increase in subsurface oxygen, but not with the increase in surface oxygen. These results provide evidence that the subsurface oxygen induced changes in electronic structure of the catalyst as well as in reactive characteristics of the oxygen adspecies are crucial to the formation of a selective surface. 5. Remote control mechanism A remote control mechanism, according to which the mobile species, such as spillover oxygen, emitted by one phase creates or regenerates active and selective sites on another phase, was put forward by Delmon and co-workers [87-89] to explain synergetic effects between separate phases frequently observed in multi- phase catalysts for selective oxidation. In their recent review paper [29], they proposed that spillover oxygen can also prevent the deactivation of the catalyst by eliminating deposited coke as well as by inhibiting deep reduction of the catalyst which leads, in certain cases, to a decomposition of the active phase. In principle, the remote control concept can be used to explain the catalyst activation caused by phase transformations during the catalytic reaction. Before such a conclusion can be reached, there must be strong evidence that neither the appearance of a new phase nor the formation of a contaminating (or supported) layer, when the surface of one phase is enriched in an element of the other phase, are responsible for the increase in activity and/or selectivity of the starting catalyst. Possible changes of oxidation state or dispersion have to be checked as well. Analysis of the literature on reaction-induced activation of selective oxidation catalysts revealed only one paper relating this phenomenon to a remote controlled cooperation between initially present and newly formed phases in the catalyst. This is our joint publication with the group of Delmon (Baidikova et al. [90] ) in which some speculations were done to explain the dramatic increase in catalytic activity of the Bi-Mn oxide during the oxidative coupling of methane. One of them was that a bismuth-depleted Bi2Mn4010-1ike phase could donate spillover oxygen to Bi203 and make it more active. From the viewpoint of the author of this review, the results reported in ref. [ 90] are more consistent with the idea that an active and selective catalyst formed under the reaction conditions has a more complicated composition than a mixture of these phases, as has been discussed above in Section 3.4. At the same time, the concept of remote control can meet with success when used as an alternative interpretation of some literature data. For instance, in Gras- selli's model for the restructured Bi-Fe-Mo oxide catalyst described in the previous section, the newly formed fl-FeMoO4 phase can be considered as a donor which dissociates molecular oxygen to form a surface mobile species. These active oxygen atoms then spill over to and irrigate the catalytically active Bi2(MoO4) 3 phase (acceptor), thus enhancing its activity. Concluding remarks In this review clear evidence has been presented that an increase in catalytic activity and/or selectivity during the reaction is widespread for oxidation catalysts. As a rule, it is caused by catalyst restructuring occurring in response to its chemical environment. Structural changes occur at the surface as well as in the bulk of catalytic systems, and different mechanisms for these changes exist. Some of them are contradictory, even when the same system is considered. The main reason for this situation is that the approaches have been made from different points of view regarding the nature of catalyst's active component. In most publications, the samples have been characterized before and after reaction in order to detect changes which might take place in the catalyst during the reaction. Such characterization of the same system carried out by different research groups may give different results since the catalyst structure after reaction frequently depends on the used reactant composition. Moreover, it may differ from the real structure operating under the conditions of the catalytic reaction. Therefore, it is very important to undertake a physico-chemical characterization during catalysis under standard conditions. There are unfortunately only few techniques available which permit in-situ meas- urements. This problem requires considerable effort and the development of new techniques to characterize in situ the catalyst dynamics, which is particularly impor- tant for understanding the real structure of the active surface with a consequent correct approach to the modelling of the reaction mechanism. The practical aspect of the considered phenomenon has become of major signif- icance in light of new nonsteady-state processing approaches to selective oxidation of hydrocarbons [92-94]. To design a catalyst able to operate effectively, for instance, under the conditions of cyclic reduction-oxidation processes, one has to know how it stores oxygen and if the stored oxygen is utilized selectively. This information can be obtained by exposing the catalyst to various reaction mixtures and detecting the changes in the catalyst resulting from these exposures. It is also important for the catalytic processes which operate under other artificially created nonsteady-state conditions with the aim to get the highest yield of the desired product. In these cases, catalyst composition changes with time-on-stream, gradu- ally reaching its steady state, and reaction kinetic measurements for a series of E.A. Mamedov / Applied Catalysis A: General 116 (1994) 49-70 catalyst compositions over the range of possible variations are to be done. Only on the basis of these data, a complete kinetic model of the process, which is needed for mathematical modelling and reactor design, can be worked out. This review concerns selective oxidation catalysts which often exhibit an increase in activity or/ and selectivity as the reaction proceeds to reach its steady state. The objective is to discuss the possible reasons of this phenomenon. The evidence is presented that the activation of most of the reviewed catalysts was caused by the reaction-induced restructuring observed to occur at the surface as well as in the bulk of catalyst. Different mechanisms, such as removal of weakly bound oxygen, creation of active sites, deposition of carbonaceous material, formation of new phases or overlayers, remote controlled cooperation between separate phases and others, are discussed. These changes in catalyst composition are to be taken into account both for modelling the reaction mechanism and kinetics.
